111111.content:
Cyrus opened his eyes.

Or he tried to open his eyes. It took some effort, as it felt that someone had used something rather thick to seal them shut, and left the remainder of the sealant in his mouth. As Cyrus tried to sit up, he found a weight on his chest. Two weights, to be exact. One blonde, one brunette. He remembered them as the two very young, very eager serving wenches who took him up on his offer of a guaranteed night of unrivaled pleasure. From the dim memories he was able to bring up through the remnants of an alcoholic haze, as well as the contented smiles upon the girls' sleeping faces, Cyrus deduced he had been able to keep his promise.

Gently slipping from beneath the sleeping forms of both young women, Cyrus made his way to a stand with a pitcher of water and a porcelain bowl, with a piece of reflective glass above it. As he watched his face, Cyrus studied the face looking back at him from the mirror. Five years past his thirtieth birthday, Cyrus was still considered a master of the long blade, a swordsman who had very few equals. But the weeks of campaigning for some fat lord or another, of searching in desolate places for legendary treasures, and yes, the carousings that followed a successful campaign or adventure, were beginning to take their toll. Cyrus knew his limitations. He was an unrivaled swordsman, and knew how to handle himself in a number of situations, and could even lead a small group of men into (and more importantly, out of) perilous situations. He had earned, found and spent several small fortunes since the age of fourteen. All notable accomplishments, particularly for the third son of a man whose job it was to tend to the swans, peacocks and other exotic birds owned by a wealthy nobleman's wife.

But Cyrus was getting to the age where men like him were captains of companies and military advisers to nobleman. And beyond directing his own sword, and the swords that fought next to him, Cyrus knew he had no talent for such things.

One more campaign, Cyrus thought to himself, as he began dressing. Enough money to buy an inn on a not-too-traveled road, where I can regale my guests about days gone past while I sit by a warm fire with a good meal in my stomach and a cup of wine in my hand. Or maybe I should find some fat nobleman who has martial dreams and serve as an instructor of blade to his sons.

As Cyrus mused these possibilities, his eyes spotted a large envelope that had been slipped under his door sometime the night before. Picking it up, Cyrus noted that the seal on the envelope had no discernible symbol. Shrugging, Cyrus broke the seal and pulled out the parchment inside the envelope, to discover that it was
111111.title: Cyrus Swanson

1111111.content:
Strangely enough, it was the fact that the writing of the note was both eloquent and clear, and the message's grammar and spelling were impeccable, that gave Cyrus some trouble deciphering the note. He was used to messages scribbled out by hurried hands in the midst of battle, from men who were more familiar with a pommel or bow in their hand than a quill or graphite stick.

Eventually, though, Cyrus' muddle brain did decipher the note, which was an invitation to visit the home of one
1111111.title: an invitation

11111111.content:
Cyrus crumpled the note in his hand and rubbed his head. The letter had invited him to visit the manor house of Lord William of Duskbloom Marsh on the far edge of the region. Apparently, there was some dire business the man needed help with and only the bravest souls and fiercest warriors would have a hope of accomplishing this task... though he conveniently forgot to mention what exactly it was... only that there would be "piles of gold and silver" as a reward.

Cyrus sighed as he sat down at his wooden table and unfolded the note again to read it over again. While he was confident in his abilities and the money promised he wasn't too sure if he felt up to dealing with such a bothersome task. Not only was the manor home a good three or four days away by horse it sat right near the center of a swampy marsh filled with unpleasantness, to say nothing of Lord William's... "eccentric" reputation. Even for a whole house made of gold was it really work the trouble?

Cyrus checked the address given and ripped it off the rest of the parchment, making sure to catch William's signature on the torn piece. "Enough to retire and then some, but nasty bugs and swamp critters are just the beginning of this little errand." Cyrus mumbled to himself as he he thought over what he might face if he showed up. "Knowing William he could very well be planning a full on civil war with those swamp inhabitants of his or maybe he just needs someone to kidnap a princess or two for him. Whatever the job... it probably won't be clean. He didn't get his reputation for kissing babies and petting puppies."

After a few minutes of careful thought Cyrus finally decided to...
11111111.title: The Offer

discover if anyone else at the inn had received an invitation

All things considered, Cyrus would have preferred not to have taken Lord William up on his invitation. The nobleman's unsavory reputation coupled with his mental instability would normally make him someone Cyrus would steer well clear of. But Lord William's money spent as well as anyone's, and "piles of gold and silver" promised to be just what Cyrus needed to retire.

With his decision firmly, if somewhat unhappily, made, Cyrus decided to...

If life had taught Cyrus anything, it was (when possible) don't make important decisions with only the taste of last night's drinking in your mouth. With that maxim in mind, Cyrus headed down to the common room.

A full stomach later (topped off with two big mugs of coffee), Cyrus was back to his usual optimistic self. The worries about encroaching middle age were pushed to the back of his mind, with thoughts of Lord William's offer were the main focus of his thoughts. Perhaps he should ask around for some more information about recent events at Duskbloom Marsh before making the ride out there, Cyrus thought to himself.

Cyrus was trying to determine who would be the best local source of information when his ponderings were interrupted by two of the King's Guard barging into the common room. Without any preliminary, one of the royal guards announced,

"We are looking for..."

Cyrus frowned as the two guardsmen walked around the common room while asking random people to submit to searches and answer questions. He certainly didn't look like the roguish type and had a fairly modest reputation as a great swordsman, but if these gentlemen knew who he was they'd almost certainly search him. Thinking quickly he deposited the the torn bit of the letter into his boot and chucked the rolled up remainder into the nearby hearth while they were distracted with a man emptying his coin purse on the nearby table.

"That's a lot of gold for someone dressed so modestly." one of the guardsman said as he picked up a handful of gold and silver coins. "It looks like there's enough here to buy a new horse and still have enough to gamble away on cards and dice. Where exactly did you get it?" The man nervously glanced around the room at the others, either looking for a word of support or a quick escape perhaps. Cyrus knew that this was probably a good time to head out.

As he got up one of the guardsmen turned away from the man with the fat purse and walked over to block his way. "Not so fast, we've not given anyone permission to leave yet, return to your seat." he ordered as he put a hand on his blade. Cyrus glanced quickly at the door behind him before turning his attention back to the guardsman. "Well? Go on then, back to your seat." he ordered again in a slightly sterner tone as he began pulling the blade from its hilt.

Cyrus had to choose his next actions very carefully...

Even in the first blush of day, with the guests still asleep from their carousing the night before, there should have still been somebody in the common room, if only one of the servants cleaning out the ashes from last night's fire.

Carl's instinct made him immediately reach for the pommel of his sword, but his finger never found the grip. Instead, he only felt a pin prick at the base of his neck, before the darkness overtook him.

Unbeknownst to Carl, Lord William had contacted him and others to retrieve certain documents thought destroyed, documents pertaining to the determination of the rightful heir to the Imperial throne. Documents that others wanted to leave unearthed.

It was thought that the documents, even if they still did indeed exist, were in a place where they could not be retrieved, no matter how skilled the retrievers. But then, nobody had expected a rustic nobleman like Lord William to have discovered their existence in the first place. So Lord William was made to look to have had a hunting accident. Such things happened to rustic noblemen all the time. And anyone who had delivered Lord William's invitation, received Lord William's invitation, or even seen the envelope was quietly dispatched,

Which meant that the owner, servants and guests of an inn were killed,. Those concerned with such situations could be quite thorough, when they saw the need. And thus the life of a swordsman born in obscurity would end in mystery, a mystery that would fade into obscurity in time.

111112.content:
To say that Kairin Hobble-ter was horse-faced would have been an insult to any horse. Her face did possess the long and narrow shape often associated with the description "horse-faced", but the features of her face possessed none of the symmetry that a good horse trader would look for before making his purchase.

Standing eighteen hands high and weighing a little more than thirteen stones, the fact that Kairin was a woman was an almost forgotten afterthought in her appearance. Kairin kept her hair short, and the dark reddish strands always had the appearance of having gone weeks without being washed (which they often did). Her customary apparel of a leather jerkin over which she would adorn a coat of mail for melee covered her already muted womanly "charms."

It is true that occasionally Kairin might be roughly approached by one of her male colleagues, motivated by curiosity or the lack of female "companionship" after weeks on a campaign, but Kairin easily (and usually violently) rebuffed such advances without a second thought. Kairin had put away all thoughts of intimacy, physical or emotional, since her childhood.

If Kairin had been born more seemly, or perhaps if she had been born somewhere other than in a herder's hut on the edge of the kingdom she lived in, her fate would have been different, and she might not be known as one of the best (if not THE best) long sword wielders in the known world. But fate had sculpted her appearance and chose her birthright, and thus Kairin had grown into the woman that she was.

At present, Kairin was sitting at a table along the wall of a nameless tavern in a nameless town. To the east were the Abun mountains, home of the tribes of wild men and other rough beings who would occasionally come down from their mountains to see if the flatlands would provide easy pickings. So there were military garrisons along the mountains where rough men had pledged to persuade the mountain creatures that there were no easy pickings here, and the towns such as the one Kairin was in sprung up, in part to provide for the needs of these rough men, martial and otherwise.

Across the table sat Ricven, the closest thing that Kairin had to a friend. Ricven was a decent enough swordsman, though he did not possess Kairin's skill. But the talent that Ricven used to make his way through the world was not his skill with a sword and shield, but the deftness with which he used his fingers and tongue. Standing six inches shorter than Kairin, Ricven could have used his lean good looks and his talent at song, whether sung or strummed, to make a decent living traveling from inn to inn (though his musical skills were lost on the tone deaf Kairin). But Ricven had an uncanny skill at negotiating the best price, whether it was for a contract for the services of himself and his companions, or for retrieving the most profit for whatever treasure he had helped recover. No lock was safe if Ricven wanted it opened, no passage or trap went undiscovered in his presence. And, as many a maiden had discovered, sometimes no virtue was left uncompromised (this was another skill which Ricven had wisely chosen never to try on his companion Kairin). Occasionally Ricven's skills would land him into trouble, but here he discovered that no father, brother or fiancée was ever outraged enough to try their skills against Kairin, his more than occasional protector.

At present, the two were waiting at their table to meet with a potential employer. Ricven drained his cup and was about to order more wine when a smile crossed his face. "I believe that is our potential employer coming toward us now." Kairin turned around to see two rather large men escorting...

111122.content:
Disaster had fallen.

Haziyah kept an eye on the sun in the sky as the women, the children, the elderly and the sick made their way slowly into the cave. Four hours until the sun set and then...who knew?

"We should not be doing this Haziyah!" Haziyah broke herself from her reverie to look down from her perch at one of the older men in the throng making its way into the cave. "We should stay. Our warriors will return." Haziyah simply raised an eyebrow at the old man, who turned a blustery red at the obvious dismissal of his prediction. "Some will return," he continued to insist.

One of their warriors had returned, Haziyah reflected. Wounded, dying. And in his final breath, he had told Haziyah of the betrayal. Of the gambit that had failed all, even the betrayer. Haziyah knew that the women, the children and the infirm had nothing to fear at present, at least not from tribes that her oasis had been feuding with for time immemorial. But those weren't the enemies she was worried about.

Haziyah wished she had more knowledge of what exactly had happened, but one thing was clear: the warriors of her tribe, the warriors of all the tribes, were dead or scattered across the sands, which meant that, as far as Haziyah and her people were concerned, they were dead.

The scattered warriors of other tribes were not what her people feared. There were other things, things that lived in the cold nights and the screaming sand storms. Things that would soon learn of the fate of the protectors of the various tribes. What other tribes would do, Haziyah did not know, nor did she truthfully care. The fate of her people was in her hands now, and the only shelter she could lead them to was the cave.

"Be quiet and move along, old man. We do not have time for your feeble words," she told the protester dismissively.

"No!" the old man said. The crowd around him stopped. "That...girl!" the old man said, gesturing at Haziyah, "She is leading us to our doom. You all know the tales of the cave. It is better to stay up here."

The old man was right, Haziyah reflected, at least about the tales. There were a number of stories about where the cave led, or what laid inside it. What might or might not be on the other side of the portcullis that had always been closed in the memory of her people. But Haziyah and the other young women who had been trained in the Art of the Carved Blade, to defend their people when the men were gone, knew what was in the night. There were always things that waited just outside the light of a lamp or torch. And those were the weak and the few. When knowledge of the death of the warriors spread through out the night...

Haziyah leaped down from her perch, and walked to the old man. Even in his younger days, when he stood straight and tall, Haziyah would have looked him in the eye. The old man faltered back a step or two in Haziyah's presence before he finally managed to stand his ground.

"Hear me, my people," Haziyah said, lifting her hands above her head. Haziyah was a striking figure even without the scimitar at her belt. She was tall as any man, broad in the shoulder, her long, dark hair bound in a single braid behind her and the white tunic and pants, depicting her status as both maiden and defender, contrasting sharply with her smooth, dark skin. Her near black eyes looked without flinching at the gathered crowd around her, and every eye she met looked down rather than meet her steely gaze.

"We all know the children's stories about what lies in the cave. But we also know what lies in the night, and this is all too real. And with our warriors gone, the defenders of our people will be hard pressed to keep them back. For now, we must seek shelter in the cave."

"NO!" The old man raised his hands above his head. "The cave is our doom. Some of our warriors live. We must remain outside until they return." This again caused a stir among the crowd.

Haziyah lifted her hands for silence. "The people must each choose for themselves where they wish to go. Those who wish to go into the cave will be allowed to go. Those who wish to stay above in the night, may do so. However," Haziyah added, again silencing the crowd, "the Defenders will all be going into the cave." Haziyah and the other woman who were trained in the Art of the Curved Blade had discussed this the night before, and were one in their decision. Whatever lied in the cave, it was still unknown. What was in the night was real, and it would relentlessly press its advantage, with the Warriors of the people gone.

"You...you cannot do this!" the old man protested.

"I am the leader of the Defenders," Haziyah said, her eyes focused solely on the old man. "Do you challenge my authority?"

The old man blanched. Even in the prime of his youth, he would not have challenged Haziyah. Her father often jokingly lamented the fact that she was born a woman, as her skills with the curved blade were unmatched by any of the men in the tribe.

Still, the old man tried to press his argument. "If the people decide..."

"The defense of the people is my decision, old man. If you wish to challenge me, find a blade and do so. Otherwise, the time for talking is over. Stay above ground or go into the cave, but be quiet, whichever you do."

Haziyah turned her back dismissively on the old man. It was the last insult he could bear. With a cry of pure rage, the old man pulled a dagger from his robes and rushed what he thought was the unprotected back of Haziyah. At what seemed the last second, Haziyah spun around and knocked the knife out of the old man's hand with one blow, and with edge of her hand, struck him on his throat, killing him instantly.

Haziyah stood staring silently at the old man's body for a few seconds, then looked up at the stunned crowd. "Each of you must decide for yourselves, whether you wish to go into the cave, or stay above, and await the night." Without a glance back, Haziyah entered the cave.

By nightfall, all of the people and there stored supplies were in the cave.

The opening of the portcullis was a simple thing. The "lock" had a strange rod placed inside it. The end of the rod inserted into the "lock" was shaped like a star, and the other end of the rod was shaped in the form of a thin ellipse. Haziyah wore a pendant around her neck that was also shaped like a star, a symbol of her status as the leader of the Defenders, which apparently would only allow her to remove the rod from the lock. One the rod was removed, the portcullis lifted up quite easily, as if it had not been in disuse for decades, if not centuries. Once the people and their supplies were on the other side of the portcullis, Haziyah placed the rod in the "lock" on the interior side of the gate, and once again the portcullis was immovable.

While the people got settled in, a little exploration showed that the tunnel led to another portcullis, with the same type of key. Again, it was demonstrated that the pendant around Haziyah's neck would allow only her to open and shut the portcullis.

"So what do we do now?" One of the other Defenders asked Haziyah.

"We'll sit up watches at both gates, though we should be safe for now, at least as long as our supplies last." Haziyah answered. "And then tomorrow..."
111122.title: Haziyah

111131.content:
"Day 360 -- Yet another visitor came to my quarters. I'm not sure what brings them here, whether I'm the only one they've ever met from my world, or the fact that I must be the only black man in this world, at least from what I can see, or maybe I've gotten some fame for my prowess in the arena. At least, it looks like the crowds are getting bigger."

Terrence put his pen down and rubbed his temples. Why his captors gave him a journal in which to write his thoughts, Terrence didn't know. But he was glad they did. As Terrence looked around his spartan quarters, there was still a part of him that wanted to believe that all this was some kind of scam, a large scale hoax, maybe even some psychological study he had unknowingly volunteered for. But he had been here for a year now, wherever here was, and here was a very real place indeed.

Almost a year ago, Terrence had been on a full scholarship at his state's major Tech school. Of course, the college scouts were all over him, as he had been an All American defensive player in both his junior and senior year. But Tech was not only close to home, it had one of the nation's top programs in structural engineering. Terrence knew he was good at football, and he might even have a shot at the pros, but that was a might. His mother wanted him close to home, and she wanted him to take advantage of the opportunity of a top rated education.

And on one fateful night, Terrence had put away his Calculus II book and went to sleep.

The next morning, he had woken up in a room that looked like something out of the Gladiator movie with Russell Crowe.

Terrence had not adjusted well. But his captors must have had experience with people from other worlds. And slowly they broke him to their purpose.

Faster than he thought possible, Terrence began training for what obviously was his new career: gladiator.

He was fitted with odd looking leather armor, and began training with a sword. It looked like a Japanese sword, a katana, though Terrence had never seen one in person, just in the movies. A slight man, almost two-thirds of Terrence's own height, came in twice a day to train Terrence. To Terrence, it seemed the only thing the little man taught him were different ways to be knocked down and bruised with the wooden katanas the two practiced with.

Then one day, Terrence was put in a practice arena with a full grown man who was also wielding a wooden katana. And Terrence demolished him.

Part of it was the fact that wherever here was, Terrence felt lighter. Terrence didn't know if this meant that here had less gravity than back where his reality was, or if there was something in the air, or what, but Terrence felt somehow more energized then he did before he came here.

Terrence found himself pitted against new opponents with his practice katana every other day. Sometimes, his opponents would have other weapons, like wooden swords that looked like something from King Arthur or Lord of the Rings, or blunted tridents, or other practice weapons. It didn't matter. Terrence always won.

Except against his instructor. His instructor, though, was kind enough to always make sure the beatings Terrence received at his hands were new and creative.

The people who ran this world looked as if they were Middle Eastern, though there eyes tended to run from crystal blue to bright green, and their hair was either burnished red or a bluish black. The men were all slim and, except for his instructor, were all about a foot shorter than Terrence's six foot three inches, give or take a couple of inches.

What the women of this world looked like, Terrence hadn't a clue, since he hadn't seen a woman since he had gotten here.

Most of his opponents were men from this world, though a few like Terrence were not. Or at least Terrence thought they must be from a world different from his own or that of the world where he currently was. Maybe they were people from different regions of this world. His opponents would range from a pale white to a dark olive in their complexion, but none as dark as Terrence. And they looked as human as he did, though there was also something off that said they weren't, such as pitch black eyes, or an extra finger on each hand, or just something minor but offsetting.

Terrence wished he knew more about what was going around him, but he was limited by a number of factors. No one had actually sat down and tried to teach him the language of this world. He had managed to learn a good deal on his own, but all of his knowledge had to do with fighting and food and sleeping. Nobody was interested in helping Terrence learn about the world outside the arena. All he needed to know (as far as his captors were concerned) was how to survive in the arena.

Then one day, Terrence was giving a real katana, and put in a real arena, and matched against an opponent with a real blade as well. And both men were made to understand that only one could leave the arena alive.

Killing his opponent had come easier to Terrence then he thought.

Once every week or so, Terrence was matched against another opponent. Sometimes they were men of this world. Sometimes they were not. Sometimes they were armed with katanas. Sometimes other weapons. Sometimes Terrence was thrown in the arena to fight a beast that looked a little like a tiger or a bear, but was just different enough for Terrence to remember he wasn't on his own world anymore.

It didn't matter. Terrence always won.

Within a year, Terrence found himself a blooded veteran of the arena.

Terrence put down his journal as his usual escort walked him to his transport. It was a closed box on wheels, without horses, but with no visible engine or other means of causing the transport to move. Stepping inside, the door closed, and the transport lurched forward, then gave no other sign of being in motion. After an indeterminate amount of time, there was another lurch and the doors were opened, and Terrence found himself in a strange new arena, where he was led to a holding cell, and then left alone. Terrence didn't have long to wait.

Trumpets (or instruments very close to trumpets) sounded in the distance, and a new set of escorts appeared at the door of Terrence's holding cell. Terrence was led down a corridor into an open arena. One bigger than he had ever seen. And as he looked across the arena, he saw a huge cage being rolled out. "I'm Robin Hood, from yonder wood, with my little bow and arrow.
I hit with ease, three out of threes, with my little bow and arrow."

"Where do you get those lyrics? Don't tell me, from that classic cartoon channel?"

John just shrugged and grinned as he looked over at his best friend, Sara. "It is a classic! From 1948!"

The two of them had gone to a yard sale earlier that morning, and John had spent two dollars on a hard plastic bow with a set of cheap arrows held together by scotch tape.

"I thought while we were out here I'd practice with them." 'Out here' was the meadow and the forest behind John's grandfather's house. John's grandfather lived on the edge of town and had a few hundred acres behind his house. It was a perfect place for a pair of friends to wander about, particularly if those friends didn't quite fit in with the mainstream at their small town high school, and especially if the two friends didn't quite know how they felt about each other.

John was a gifted young writer who often found himself living not quite wholly in the world his body was confined to, which sometimes made him the target of ridicule when he was "spaced out." Sarah was a young woman gifted in mathematics but not so much in the social graces. Though neither overweight nor homely, she did carry a few more pounds than what her peers thought was acceptable, and her skin was not without a few blemishes. Add that to her intellect, and Sarah was often made to feel as if she was on the outside looking in. Somehow, she and John had gravitated toward each other, and Sarah, in her most honest moments, wished she and John might have gravitated even closer together. John, though, seemed oblivious to the possibility of anything more than friendship.

Sarah was glad John had decided to take his archery experiment out into the woods, though she was sure that this latest adventure of his would make its way back to school.

"Well, I'd like to explore the cave a little bit more," Sarah said. John just grunted noncommittally but followed Sarah as she led the way.

There was a small cave on John's grandfather's property. It was nothing grand, and the cave did not go very far back. At least not the part that was accessible. The only reason that flashlights were even necessary was so that Sarah and John could peer down the small holes along the back. They had never found anything interesting in all the holes, but they would look in them for a few minutes before sitting down and chatting, or working on their own projects while enjoying a companionable silence. By unspoken mutual agreement, the cave was their secret, shared with no one.

They reached the cave, and Sarah immediately pulled out her flashlight. John turned his attention to the cheap bow in his hand, plucking at the thick piece of twine that serve as the bowstring. Sarah was about to say something, but instead kept quiet, as she began the ritual of going into the cave and shining the flashlight down the various holes. As usual, she found nothing. Until...

"John, there's something down this hole. John, are you listening to me?" Sarah turned back to say something caustic to get John's attention, when a bright light flashed from the hole, casting the cave and the two young adults in a blinding white light.

When the light faded, John and Sarah were facing each other. Except the other had changed. Significantly.

It was not that their looks had changed. It was as if someone had taken their bodies as templates, and brought out all the potential each one had. John had always been a tall, gangly kid, but now he was tall and leanly muscled. His sparse facial hair, only needing to be shaved every three or four days, was now a tightly trimmed mustache and goatee, and his unkempt hair was braided to the middle of his back. The cheap bow and arrows were now a tall bow made of yew, as tall as John himself, and there was a quarrel of poplar arrows on his back. John found himself clad in some type of leather armor, with a rather large dagger (or short sword?) at his waist.

And Sarah had gone through the same transformation. Her hair was long now, rich and thick in texture, a slightly darker red. Her skin was fair and perfect, her green eyes sharp and piercing, and she had a body that was fit and feminine. And she wore the garb of

"When any of you lads can place an arrow at such a target, you may freely call yourself men of Saethwr Shire, and not a day before. Now back to your targets."

Instead, her gaze was solely focused on the middle-aged man, who walked over to her and clapped a hand on her shoulder.

"Except for you, father," Rosalind said, the blush on her fair cheeks clearly visible.

Not that she wasn't as fair as any maid in the shire, with her slender curves, fair skin and soft red hair. She looked out across the countryside, watching the rolling hills disappear into the horizon.

Nothing.

Standing on the rampart of her family's summer palace, she hadn't really expected to see anything. Oh, there were things to see. In the distance, she could just make out a small herd of sheep. Their guardian was no doubt somewhere nearby, taking a nap. This close to the Castle Gilbert, Tara doubted there was even a feral dog that might fleetingly think of disturbing the peace.

In the distance, she could just make out a few smoke puffs making their way lazily upward. That would be one of the steamships, making its way down the Illivan river, no doubt carrying passengers and freight to the seaport city of Avonarc. Or it might even be towing coal barges to one the growing factory towns that dotted the banks of the Illivan..

Tara hefted the crossbow in her hand as she added the arts of war to that mental list. Attached to the underside of the crossbow was a large, brass cylinder that made even a novice with the weapon a deadly opponent. And Tara was anything by a novice.

For now, the Grand Duchy of Gilbert had an advantage over its neighbors. No doubt in time the kingdoms and empires bordering Gilbert would secure similar weapons of their own, but Gilbert controlled the largest deposits of coal on the continent, and without coal, steam magic could not be performed.

Yes, all was well with the Grandy Duchy of Gilbert.

Which did not set well with Tara.

Not that she begrudged the people of Gilbert the good times they were enjoying. But for the youngest of the seven children of the Grand Duke of Gilbert, that prosperity came at a price. As she approached her sixteenth birthday, Tara knew that she would soon be married off for the purpose of securing diplomatic relations with one of Gilbert's neighbors. There was even the chance that she could be wedded to a master of one the duchy's more prosperous guilds. And as a young woman who was beautifully blossoming, Tara knew that he potential suitors held more than a casual interest in her burgeoning beauty.

Unfair, Tara screamed silently in her head as she stormed off the ramparts and into an adjoining tower. In more turbulent times, the ramparts and towers would have been manned, but the Grand Duchy of Gilbert had pushed its borders further out and along the walls of the summer palace, Tara only had to worry about encountering the occasional ceremonial guard.

Agrafi looked out across the endless plains from the knoll she and her steed had paused on. There were no sign of the dark invaders, the Chernakozy, and they were not a subtle people. Chernakozy men were slothful and rapacious, Chernakozy women were slatternly and licentious, and all Chernakozy were incapable of providing for themselves. The only thing Chernakozy were good for was waging war on the various tribes of the Plains. And at this, they were only good if they could force the people of the Plains into battles where there strange, smoke issuing sticks could be brought to bear. Fortunately, the people of the Plains had learned early on to avoid the mass groupings of Chernakozy fighters, using their longer ranged bows to prick and irritate Chernakozy war bands and lead them into ambushes. The Chernakozy had finally learned to stay in their strange, impregnable structures at the edge of the Plains, and to ignore the provocations of warriors like Agrafi. Instead, the Chernakozy would send mass groups of fighters out to despoil random parts of the Plains.

Things had been this way Agrafi and, twenty years later, it was still the same. Each side had learned about the other, but not enough to disturb the equilibrium. The tribes of the Plains had learned the Chernakozy were little more than beasts, who knew how to operate weapons they fought with, but little else. The Chernakozy leaders and sub-leaders who were captured spoke of Wizards of Sand who ruled incredible cities beyond the mountain ranges to the East of the Plains, from which mountain passes the Chernakozy had emerged from a generation ago. What these Wizards of Sand wanted in the Plains, the Chernakozy did not know.

111331.content:
As many and most stories have begun before, this one is now destined to begin with a man. There seems to be something about this gender that is the reason for a very dominating presence in society throughout history, but whether this is good or bad is up to every single individual alone to decide.

Our hero of the story, Temujin, never thought about this of course. He is a respected herder who lives just a half-day ride outside of his very small village, called Holon Tolgoi, exactly halfway between Khatanbulag and Ulaanbadrakh. Although, compared to the western tradition of defining the word `village´, it is quite an exaggeration to even call it a `small village´. Three small yurts and a big one. That’s it. In the middle of nowhere. The “village” isn’t supplied by anything, except Temujin who frequents weekly visits where he brings raw meat and goat milk. By now, you should know though that Temujin is very over qualified for this job, as he has served in many wars against Chinese tribes during his younger years, thus earning him the high honor of a chivalric warrior. But the people of Holon Tolgoi need him. Fifteen citizens who are absolutely and unequivocally dependent on him, because in the nomadic desert lands of southern Mongolia there are far greater dangers than starvation and cold nights.

Therefore, our story starts here, but of course, it would be a lie to say that it had nothing to do with a certain woman, living in Holon Tolgoi as well, named Sarnai who in fact was the very reason that Temujin rode to Holon Tolgoi to manage his farm outside of the village. She had made him promise to settle down, if he survived the last war, he had fought in. But enough of the past. The present keeps going, no matter how long we dwell in history.

The year is 1230. While the high middle age is dominating Europe and the black death is haunting innocent Europeans, Temujin has just started yet another ride to Holon Tolgoi, accompanied by a small portion of his herd. He is planning to instate a local herder there to take care of a few oxen as well, since the population in Holon Tolgoi is on the verge of increasing. So, Temujin thought it would be a good idea to create a less dependent demand in the village. His Mongol horse, Khunbish, is stepping energetically through the rough, rocky wasteland. He gave it five liters of fresh water to drink, right before they took off. When they arrive, it will drink five more.

“You have always been a thirsty one, Khun. Haven’t you?” Temujin says with a gentle clap on Khunbish’ shoulder.

Khunbish reciprocates the gesture with a loud neigh, which makes the herd around them shoo away a little, but with a firm “hiya!” Temujin makes Khunbish gallop in a circle around the herd to drive them together again, where after they ride up in front of the herd again, leading them on the right path.

`Let’s see what the deserts around Tolgoi have to offer us this time´, Temujin thinks to himself.

After a few minutes of enjoying the view on some snowy mountain tops in the distance, Temujin suddenly hears the sound of one of his oxen, tripping and falling to the ground with an excruciating loud roar that makes the entire heard panic.

Temujin pulls the cords of the bridle to make Khunbish turn quickly to the left. With invigorating fury, Khunbish races around back around the herd, performing aggressively fast jumps into the herd every now and then to make the animals gather closer. It only takes a few dozen seconds to get the whole herd of two oxen and five cows driven together.

“Prrrrr.” Temujin says to calm Khunbish down.

As he gets of the Mongol horse, he slowly walks towards the remaining ox, which has fallen and is bleeding rather badly out of its leg.

“Easy now.” Temujin says calmly, as he steadily approaches the ox. He is considering ripping a sleeve of his deel off and wrap it around the leg of the ox. Two oxen aren’t much to bring to Holon Tolgoi, but on the other side, the materials needed to make a new deel aren’t easy to acquire either.

As Temujin stands there for a few seconds and ponders what he is going to do, he notices a crack in the ground, which, he realizes, is expanding more and more every second. This is probably the reason, why the ox tripped. Its foot must have gotten stuck in there during the galloping.

Before Temujin realizes the severity of the situation, he is already looking at a five-meter-wide opening, which has uncovered a huge ravine underneath it. His ox is still laying on the ground, no more than a few inches from the cliff, adjacent to the ravine. He has never seen anything like this before. What is down there?

Even with his background as a fearless warrior, Temujin now has to swallow a small lump in his throat. But as he regains his confident courage and steadily walks towards the edge of the cliff, he notices what looks like a bunch of stone stairs, which seem to shoot out from the rocky wall right underneath him, almost as if to form a staircase down into the ravine.

Intrigued, Temujin takes a while to ponder his decision about what to do next?

He could explore the staircase, leading down into the ravine, a little, but he reminds himself that he doesn’t know yet, why the ravine suddenly has opened itself up, and he certainly doesn’t know what or who is behind this. Usually, when something opens, like a gate for instance, you’d expect someone or something to go through it. Right? This could be dangerous perhaps. And also, there are people in Holon Tolgoi who depend on him to make it back there by the end of the day. Furthermore, what does he do about his wounded ox?

Temujin has to take a few minutes to process all of this…

As Mugow peered south through her telescope from the top of the sentry tower, the men garrisoned at said post took the opportunity to surreptitiously observe her beauty. Mugow had the slender curves of a young girl just blossoming into a woman, with flawless light olive skin that hinted that perhaps at least one of her grandparents came from south of the Wall. Her hair, though, was the flawless black night color that was common to the women of the Northern Kingdom, and there was no hint of southern ancestry in her soft brown eyes. If it were not for the Warrant she wore openly on the right breast of her tunic, one or two of the men of the garrison might have been tempted to forcefully sample her ripening beauty, regardless of the fact that she, like them, wore the tunic of an Imperial soldier.

But Mugow Kwai also wore the Warrant of the Emperor, and to dishonor that Warrant was to bring not only a painful death to the man who dishonored that Warrant, but also that death to his kin, and a public dishonor to his ancestors.

Mugow collapsed her telescope and re-entered the sentry tower. She was either oblivious the covert glances she was receiving from the men of the tower garrison, or simply chose to ignore them. She exchanged a few words with the garrison commander and asked if there was any messages she could deliver for him. The commander thanked her for her generosity, and handed her two scrolls, one for the commander of the next tower garrison she would visit, and a report for his immediate superior. With a slight bow of her head to the garrison commander, she took her leave.

Mugow carefully adjusted the objects on her belt and spent a few minutes stretching, before beginning her run.

There was nothing unusual about a runner along the top of the Great Wall of the Northern Kingdom. Each garrison commander always had one or two of his men whom he used as a fast messenger to his immediate neighbor to the east or west. And then, of course, each tower kept dung and firewood ready to light its beacon, in case of invasion from the South. And the major outposts had stables of horses, so that more detailed information could be sent to the Generals as soon as the warning fires were lit.

And, of course, all the Generals had their own messengers, both foot and horse. There was even talk that scholars and mages of the Imperial Court were developing a method by which mirrors could send messages over the miles, though nothing had come of this, save gossip.

And then there were the messengers who wore the Warrants, such as Mugow Kwai.

They were merely runners, though they ran great distances with relative ease. They were trained in a number of skills, and carried an odd assortment of light and collapsible tools on their belts, including a dagger which rumor attributed a number of arcane traits to. Whether any of these rumors were true or not, only the messengers who wore the Warrant knew. What was known, though, were those who wore the Warrant were resourceful, insightful people.

Part of this insightfulness was the fact that a garrison commander who might be reluctant to tell his superior about a shortcoming in his command might be more open to someone holding a Warrant, since an observation to a Warrant messenger would not (necessarily) be traceable to a commander making an observation. And the Warrant messengers were trained in a number of disciplines.

All Messengers bearing the Imperial Warrant reported to High General Towhi Chongdain and, if necessary, could speak with his authority. But that was in theory, and in the history of the Warrant, only one messenger had ever ordered a large movement of Imperial troops. In reality, the most 'authority' a Warrant Messenger had ever asserted might be the commandeering of a few men or materials, or perhaps an immediate audience with a Minister or General. And even such urgent audiences were always made in unfailingly polite, if determined, tones.

None of these thoughts were going through the mind of Mugow Kwai. She was more concerned with her present mission. It was not an important one to the Empire, but it was important for her. It was the first time she had ever been very far away from the Imperial Army's Headquarters, and now she found herself running the Wall! And the officers! They were not only respectful to her, but some seemed overwhelmed at the opportunity to talk to a Messenger with a Warrant. Mugow had already accumulated a tome of things memorized to report.

Mugow had to constantly remind herself that the men of the Wall were the important ones, not her, no matter how reverently they treated her. True, she was treated with respect in the Imperial City, but that was always tempered with the fact the Imperial City was overflowing with important people, and she was, after all, an untested Warrant Messenger. But here, she felt as if she were truly the eyes, ear and speech of the High General, and not simply a young woman whom someone once thought might have promise.

Mugow allowed the run to balance her thoughts and to purge herself of her giddiness. For a garrison runner, the distance to the next tower would be about fifteen minutes, but Mugow could easily run it nine, eight if she felt the reason to be there faster was unusually compelling. And since she was running the distance at the more "leisurely" pace of nine minutes, Mugow's training brought her to a halt even before she realized why she was stopping. Her hand reached toward her belt and plucked her telescope as she peered at the small dot on the horizon her peripheral vision had spotted and which made her subconscious brain bring her to a stop.

Mugow expanded her telescope and looked out at the distance. The sight she saw made her gasp. It was

There is no such thing as a dwarven kingdom.

That is not to say that dwarves do not have kings. But they are not kings as men understand kings. Men rule under men with force, with persuasion and with guile. When a man rules, he bends other men to his rule. The men who bend do so willingly, understanding the necessity, but it is not a natural state for men, and within a generation, men will chafe under a yoke, no matter how light it is.

By contrast, a dwarven king is almost a physical manifestation of his people to united so that they can work toward a common purpose. And thus a dwarven king will always work for what he perceives is the common good of his people. That is not to say that a dwarven king is without flaws, for the dwarves themselves have many flaws, as do the folks around them. But if a human king gathers wealth, it is to appease his own avarice. A dwarven king's "avarice" in amassing treasure is to reflect the glory of his people, and is seen as such among his subjects.

And a dwarven 'kingdom' is not what an outsider might think it to be. Let us take, as an example, the dwarven kingdom that is Deyrnas. While it is true that many of its citizens will be born, live and die without seeing the sun directly (though they will know its light, through methods magical, mechanical and mundane), not a few will spend their time above the ground. There are the merchants, of course, who travel to other dwarven kingdoms and the cities and towns of other races. And in small protected valleys, there are terrace farms and shelter pastures that provide the wheat and cattle for the bread, beer, butter and mutton that grace dwarven tables. And of course there are the legendary dwarven warriors. Not all dwarves are armed with axe and hammer, for there are times when it is necessary to keep (and kill) an enemy at a distance. And dwarves are very good at devising and using devices that keep (and kill) their enemies at a distance.

There are all sorts of small entrances into Deyrnas, from the hole that allows the shepherd to bring his flock and himself inside the mountain, to shafts that allow the sun (but not the elements) to enter the upper chambers of Deyrnas, and each of these has their wards and protections. But it is the Great Gate of Deyrnas where the skill of the dwarves is most evident. It is the gate from which the strength of Deyrnas will issue forth when their allies call, and it is the gate which any enemy must possess when assaulting Deyrnas. Sir James Raconis was not sure what he expected when he was told that a dwarf, a female dwarf, was being assigned to the defense he was commanding.

Raicheal Calcitegold was definitely not it, though.

Of course, it was not unusual for Sir James not to have a definite idea of what to expect from a female dwarf. It seemed that there had never been a time that the men of the Kingdom of Ancra and the dwarven tribes of the Punican Mountains were not allies, but save for the markets, the two races rarely had need to intermingle with each other. In addition, the dwarven race had always been reluctant to allow their womenfolk to venture above ground, so generations could pass before a dwarven female might be seen by the humans of the Kingdom.

But these were, in the words of the ancient curse, "interesting times."

The Punican Mountains were only a part of a great range of mountains that stretched for thousands of leagues. The Kingdom of Ancra consisted a number of passes and valleys that connected the great steppes to the east and the green fields and vast forests to the West. As such, the Kingdom straddled the major trade route between the civilizations that existed on either side of the Kingdom.

As one can imagine, the wealth of the Kingdom of Ancra had attracted more than one envious eye, from both East and West. But even among their own folk, the dwarves of the Punican Mountains were known for the superiority of their strongholds, and these skills they gladly lent to their human allies. Add to this fact that the men of Ancra were unequalled in their skill with any missile, whether it be an arrow or ballista projectile, and the Kingdom of Ancra felt itself safe behind its defenses against any foe that might rise up against it, either from East or West.

And then five years ago, Hocox the Remorseless began uniting the tribes of the Great Steppes.

There were sea kingdoms beyond the Steppes of the East, this much was known. Traders from these kingdoms would come and sell their goods at the markets of Ancra, and sometimes travel beyond, and the traders from the Kingdoms of the West would also venture to the East, and bring back tales of ships as huge as small towns that would sail across endless seas.

The road that stretched between the Kingdom of Ancra and the Kingdoms of the West with the Eastern Sea Kingdoms was commonly referred to as the Spice Road, and stretches of it went through an ever-changing control of various tribes of horsemen that roamed the steppes. There were even a handful of walled cities along the Spice Road,that had grown out of markets and bazaars that had traded for generations with the horsemen. Through a series of treaties, bribes, threats, tribute and military adventures, the Eastern Sea Kingdoms kept the roads clear for their merchants.

But then Hocox the Remorseless brought all the horsemen of the Steppes under his rule. And not just the Horsemen. Mountain goblins and other unsavory creatures also fell under his sway. The nearest walled cities along the Spice Road were known to have been pillaged and razed by Hocox and his hoardes. What fate had befallen the Eastern Sea Kingdoms, no one knew, but it was kknown that the hordes of Hocox had fallen upon the Kingdom of Ancra.

And there they were stopped. For now.

The walled and guarded passes of the Kingdom were such that it limited the amount of force that Hocox could bring to bear at a strongpoint, and the men of Ancra had centuries of tradition and experience in defending their walls. But the horde of Hocox was seemingly infinite, and though Hocox had no knowledge of conducting a siege, he was learning. In addition, Hocox had at his service the mountain goblins who, though crude and ignorant in their knowledge in comparison to the dwarves, did know something of the nature of stone. And the cheiftans of the mountain goblins held the lives of their tribesman in little regard, thinking nothing of throwing away the lives of a hundred goblin warriors to test the strength of this rampart or that bastion.

But for now, the Kingdom of Ancra held. And although the kingdoms of the West had made tentative offers (knowing that if Ancra fell, the hordes of Hocox would pour unchecked into the West), the men of Ancra were content (for now) with the aid of their oldest and only allies, the dwarves of the Punican Mountains.

Sir James Raconis commanded the garrison on the wall guarding a minor pass. Even if the wall were breached, the valley behind him led to a narrow pass that was guarded by an extension of fortress that held the Kingdom's main pass to the East. Still, it would not do to give Hocox an avenue in which to bring more force to bear on the main gate. The wall must hold.

And to that end Raicheal Calcitegold had been sent.

One on hand she was very clearly a dwarf. She stood only four foot tall, and although the men of Ancra were of average height (Sir James being an exception, at six foot tall), they still stood a foot and half over their new dwarven companion. She was stoutly built. Not fat, by any means, but she had wide shoulders and their was a certain strength in her physical stature. She wore chain mail over her leather jerkin, and wore her blondish-red hair in braids, as was the dwarven custom among both sexes of her races.

Some of the men might have been surprised that she had no beard, or any signs that she had ever had one, as it was speculated that dwarven women were bearded as well. But Raicheal's face was smooth and attractive, with a small mouth and nose and sparkling green eyes.

And Raicheal's firm, pronounced bosom, even clad in chain and leather, definitely spoke of her being a woman.

The men of the wall definitely noticed. They had been on their posts for months now, and the few hamlets in the valley behind them had been vacated, so that Raicheal had been the first woman any of them had seen for weeks. If Raicheal noticed their reaction to her gender, she pretended not to, and the ever present scowl on Sir James' face made sure that Raicheal was always treated with respect.

When she was awake, Raicheal was in motion, often with Sir James in tow, pointing out possible weak points that must be shored up, and advising him on the probable tactics of the slowly increasing number of siege engines that were being brought to bear on the wall Sir James was pledged to protect. Initially, Sir James made sure that Raicheal slept in his presence, if only to ensure that nothing untoward happened to her at the hands of his men. But as time passed, he kept her nearby more so that he could have her counsel when the wall was attacked.

And so one night, five weeks after Raicheal had arrived, both she and James were awaked by the sentry. The sentry led the pair to one of the walls towers, and handed Sir James a dwarven telescope.

Sir James' grunted in agreement, happy to have any advantage he could. He almost immediately spotted what the sentry had woken him up for. He handed the telescope to Raicheal. Oscar had found Yohanna as a baby, while hunting in the woods at the base of the Iron Mountains. Although rare, there were stories enough that the dwarves of the Iron Mountain would abandon those of their young whom they considered too far removed from whatever the standard of a proper dwarf was. Most of the stories told of some obvious deformity, and if such a baby was found by a human, custom was to leave it where it was.

Oscar didn't know. All he knew was that he could not leave her to die. When he brought her home, his wife agreed.

Oscar was the village smith, well respected both in his trade and in his habits, and though there might be some mumblings, no one would openly gainsay his choice. And it was not like the village ever saw a dwarf. There were a fair at the village of Bergspass every year, where the dwarves would trade metals, tools and other objects for the fruits and wares of the humans who came from the surrounding areas, But outside of that fair, dwarves were hardly ever seen, preferring to remain under their mountains.

She did love watching her father at work, and would even help him at small tasks, all the while seeming to know instinctively how to stay out of his (and harm's) way in the smithy.

And as boys are oft to do, they become fascinated with this development in girls their own age, and sometimes wanted to explore these developments more intimately, usually with a rough grab or a poke before running away. Usually this resulted in a slap from the offended female, or a stern talk from an elder who has learned of this venture from the distressed, offended female.

Halfling society developed independently on a peninsula and a string of islands, separated from the rest of their world by a range of impassible mountains and unnavigable waters. The seas between their islands are quite navigable.

Halfling society tends to be very class oriented, with movement between the various strata being very limited. Theoretically, the peninsula that the halflings reside on, and the string of islands, are all under the control of the port city of Jarta. However, the further away from Jarta one travels, the more autonomous the provinces become,. The furthest islands are theoretically protectorates, but in actuality these islands are under control of various tribes, with only a few fortified enclaves maintaining a royal presence.

Halfling features tend to run along Scandinavian lines, with brown eyes unheard of, and dark hair very rare. Halfling women with dark hair and blue eyes are usually considered exotic beauties. (The halfling equivalent of Helen of Troy was supposedly such a woman),

The halflings knew there was a world beyond their kingdom, but until recent history, they only had hints of what might lie beyond the turbulent seas surrounding their world. That is, until thirty years ago, when a dwarven ship, the Forge, was able to 'push through' the Maelstrom of Flores, thanks to an engine that combined dwarven magery and steam technology. A merchant's enclave of outsiders now exists in the city of Jarta and is under the protection of the present King of the Floresians (as halflings are known to outsiders). Non-halflings are not allowed to go beyond the city walls of Jarta, by royal decree. A few other races have made it to Jarta, but the vast majority of non-halflings are dwarves. Dwarves do not enjoy the best of reputations among the halflings they deal with, but at present, the dwarven monopoly on steam technology has given dwarves the upper hand, This may be changing, as halfling craftsmen and mages have recently built their own steamship, called the Balance, that will set sail. The mood of the men around him was an odd mixture of grim and festive. It was the first night of the hunt for the wyrm. And even there, the wyrms were never seen, save perhaps once or twice in a generation when a wyrm would come down from the mountains, taking a few heads of cattle in the middle of the night. The local ranchers would respond by forming a hunting party, with the men arming themselves with crossbows with enough force to pierce the tough hide of the wyrms.

The older men who had participated in the last wyrm hunt, fifteen years ago, went about setting up camp with grim countenances. They knew that the wyrm they were hunting could easily be twice as long as a man was high, with vicious teeth and claws. The animal would avoid humans, moving mostly at night. All the young men except Sica Redstone.

The Wyrms weren't the only exotic creatures that lived in the Segila Mountains. Tribes of elves lived there as well, rarely ever seen, save as shadows in the moonlight.

On occasion, under a summer moon, an elven female would appear to a young human male, luring him into the woods and engaging him in a week of wild abandonment..

The next year, as the snows began melting, a child would appear just outside the main village, on an odd rock formation made of red stone.

"Excellent, Xandril. But I have come to expect nothing less than perfection from you," the older woman said, as she lifted the cup in her hand to her lips, taking another small sip of the hot brown liquid Xandril had recently served her.

Not that it was surprising that Xandril could brew and serve and excellent cup of tea. He was, after all, a Mivorean, which was both the name of the region, and the people that lived there. Strictly speaking, Mivoreans weren't a separate race, but the end product of the generations of the (usually) peaceful 'interaction' of the humans of the Empire to the north, south and west of their region, and the elves of the great forests and mountains to their east, an 'interaction' which continued to the present day.

And, strictly speak, Mivore had not existed since the second Dynasty of the Empire (the Empire was presently in its Fifth Dynasty). Speaking correctly and officially, Mivore was part of the Province of TianHu, and directly ruled by the Governor of said Province, who was directly appointed and served at the Sufferance of the Empress of the only True Empire. In reality, the region of Mivorean was ruled by a council of elders and were usually left to their own devices as long as the proper taxes were paid, the proper forms were filled and there were no major disruptions going on anywhere in the Empire. And the reason for this was simple.

Tea.

Mivore wasn't the only source of tea in the world, but the argument could be made that it was the source of best and most varied types of teas known to the civilized races of the world. There were teas for bringing bright thought to the drinker in the morning, and teas that eased the drinker into sleep at night. Tea to ease pain, heal sickness, increase stamina.;;the list was endless. And among the Mivoreans, there were many families well known (at least among their fellow Mivoreans) for their skills in different aspects of the tea trade. Xandril's own family had many members, past and present, known for their skills in harvesting different tea leaves, no matter how much skill and delicacy was required.

Most famed among the Mivoreans were a class called the Brewers, men and women adept at creating new strains of teas, and bringing out the best of the old. Different skills were attributed to the Brewers, from being able to predict future events by merely reading tea leaves to being able to heal the sick and the infirm, if they had access to their own private collection of tea leaves.

And among the Brewers, there were the Adepts, the ones considered steeped in the lore of Mivorean tea, and where considered truly powerful. It was rumored a Brewer Adept could cloud and control the minds of all but the most strong-willed, subtly alter the weather about them, and other equally remarkable (and unbelievable) arcane skills. It was the Adepts who would choose from among the Mivoreans who would train to become Brewers and who keep their eyes on the new apprentices, in case one had the markings of eventually becoming an Adept.

Xandril was one such young man.

It was an unusual romance, even as such tales goes between men and elves. Her name was Mirana Iceter, though she was more commonly known in the days of her youth as the Twin Axe. She was the youngest daughter of one of the many chiefs of the tribes of the North Men. When she was twelve, her father was betrayed by one of his advisers, and her entire family was slaughtered. The only reason that Mirana had survived was that she caught the lustful eye of the man who betrayed and killed her father. When she was brought to the man's tent, she was able to kill him, and escaped. With the aid of her father's only loyal adviser, Mirana somehow managed to not only exact her revenge on the men who had plotted against her father, but was also able to unite the North Men under her banner. At the age of twenty, Mirana "Twin Axe" Iceter gathered the hordes of the Northmen and marched to the South, destroying anyone and anything in her path who did not bend their knee to her and pay her tribute.

And it was here that the elven prince Finrod Faelivrin enters the tale. Finrod was the nephew of the king of Tithris, an ancient city and forest that laid in the path of the ravaging North Men. It was known that Mirana blamed the death of her father partly on a tribe of dwarves who coveted certain rare metals in her tribe's lands, and had helped in the machinations against Mirana's father. So Mirana held very little love for any race besides human. For his part, Finrod had only known the tales travelers told of the North Men, and had always been happy that they never left their frigid homes. But now they were marching south, and it was said they did not plan to leave a single tree or elf alive in Tithris.

So Finrod, at his uncle's behest, went north under a banner of truce, hoping against hope of saving his people. As for his own life, Finrod considered it forfeit the moment he started north.

And then a strange thing happened. Not immediately. Although it was considered strange by some that Mirana didn't have Finrod killed as soon as he was brought before her. But somehow, over the length of two years, Finrod's captivity, which seemed to be about to end in his death at a moment's notice, became a romance. And at the age of twenty-two, Queen Mirana, undisputed mistress of the lands of the North and the kingdoms that bordered on them, took Finrod Faelivrin as her Prince Consort.

And a year later, she gave him three children.

In the two decades from the moment he was presented to Queen Mirana, a strange alliance formed between the Elves of Tithris and the North Men. The North Men did not march further south, burning and plundering everything in their path, but instead took root, solidifying their hold on those lands they had conquered. Rule of law was established, and justice, though still rough, ruled the new Empire of the North, with the Elves of Tithris serving more oft than not as important councilors in the various courts of the Empire.

And on their eighteenth birthday, the three children of the Queen and her Consort presented themselves before their parents, and were sent on a quest, to determine which child would one day inherit the Throne of the North.

info.brief_description: An interactive fantasy adventure where the reader decides what happens next to the hero
info.description:
This is a nostalgic tribute to a series of books I had as a young lad, in which the reader chose different paths as he or she guided the hero through a fantasy world. It's also been something of a writing/imagination exercise for myself, as I have forced myself to come up with multiple worlds for the reader/potential contributor to enter. For those who wish to contribute, I ask the following:

1) Please add more than just a sentence or two to your addition. Two or three paragraphs at a minimum would be nice

2) Please maintain a continuity with the storyline in your addition.

3) Please do not make the word 'Continue' or anything similar one or both of the options the reader has to choose from

4) All good stories must eventually come to an end. However, I would prefer no storyline ends prior to Chapter 10.

5) I understand that there are a number of special interests that some might deem 'fetishes' on WDC. I would prefer that they do not enter this interactive.

6) Remember the '13' rating when adding on to the story, particularly with any scenes involving violence or romance

I reserve the right to edit or delete any contributions, though I will try to do so sparingly, especially if the contributor has complied with my guidelines above. In addition, for anyone who doesn't wish to contribute but would like to see a particular storyline expanded, just send me an email and I'll be happy to oblige. Be advised I am working on other projects now, and any additions you want me to make are going to be on a as time becomes available basis.
